steps.name: parflowSandtank
steps.guidance: As we learned in the first video, the ParFlow Sandtank runs a physically based model that incorporates characteristics, like permeability, to model an environment. In the section below, we will run a physically based simulation and generate an output.

steps.name: changeSlider
steps.guidance: Set the boundary conditions by dragging the sliders up or down to change the values. Notice the scale for permeability on the right; you can see it goes from low permeability to high permeability. When you’ve set the boundary sliders where you’d like them to be, click on the "Run Simulation" button.

steps.name: simulationWater
steps.guidance: After a few moments, you can see the simulation generated a pressure (purple) output and a saturation (blue) output, which you can toggle between using the icon in the lower left corner of the image.

steps.name: advanceAfterSimulationWater
steps.guidance: After a few moments, you can see the simulation generated a pressure (purple) output and a saturation (blue) output, which you can toggle between using the icon in the lower left corner of the image.

steps.name: addAI
steps.guidance: Now that we have our goal output, we can get into machine learning! You can click on the "+" button to add rows for machine learning models.

steps.name: selectModel
steps.guidance: Now let's select how we want our ML models to be trained using the "Training Set" dropdown. You can select between three options: all, wet, or dry. All has been trained on the complete data set, including both dry and wet conditions. Wet has been trained only using boundary conditions that represent wet conditions (larger numbers). Dry has been trained only using dry boundary conditions (smaller numbers). Make your choices then click on the "Run ML Models" button to begin.

steps.name: compareAIWater
steps.guidance: Now let’s look at some outputs. The ML Output lets you visually compare the outputs from the ML models to the physically based (“goal”) simulation. Do these outputs look similar? Do they look different? If so, how are they different? Don't forget to toggle between the pressure (purple) and saturation (blue) outputs using the icon in the lower left corner!

steps.name: advanceAfterCompareAIWater
steps.guidance: Now let’s look at some outputs. The ML Output lets you visually compare the outputs from the ML models to the physically based (“goal”) simulation. Do these outputs look similar? Do they look different? If so, how are they different? Don't forget to toggle between the pressure (purple) and saturation (blue) outputs using the icon in the lower left corner!

steps.name: noticeAIDiff
steps.guidance: The next output below is Simulation vs. ML, where you can see the amount and location of difference between the outputs from the ML models and the physically based simulation. The darker shade indicates a greater difference and a lighter shade indicates a smaller difference. Where do you see the most difference between the simulation and ML? If you’d like to learn more about this, check out our lessons that dive deeper into these topics. Again, don’t forget to toggle between pressure and saturation outputs.

steps.name: advanceAfterNoticeAIDiff
steps.guidance: The next output below is Simulation vs. ML, where you can see the amount and location of difference between the outputs from the ML models and the physically based simulation. The darker shade indicates a greater difference and a lighter shade indicates a smaller difference. Where do you see the most difference between the simulation and ML? If you’d like to learn more about this, check out our lessons that dive deeper into these topics. Again, don’t forget to toggle between pressure and saturation outputs.

steps.name: noticeErrorDist
steps.guidance: The last output allows us to see how many errors were encountered and how these errors are distributed. First, make sure you have the ML Output toggled to saturation (blue). The distribution of errors should be a pie chart, where you can see the number of correctly predicted pixels ("accuracies") and the number of incorrectly predicted pixels, or "errors". This can give you an idea of how well your ML model predicted the same outcome as your goal simulation. When you toggle your ML Output to pressure (purple), you can see the distribution of errors is now displayed as a bar graph, which shows the value of the error and how many pixels had that same error value. If you’re curious about pixels and errors, check out our resources page to learn more!

Now that you know the basics of the Sandtank-ML app, explore different inputs and variables to see how they impact machine learning predictions. Also, please check out more lessons and content on our Resources page.
